stories.headline: Audit: Board can’t pay fees for legal fight
stories.summary: An attorney hired by the Arkansas Board of Corrections to handle a lawsuit against Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders is owed more than $200,000, a state audit concluded, because the board has no way to pay the contract. The audit, released during a Legislative Joint Auditing Committee meeting, noted the attorney has not been paid at least $230,108 as of Feb. 11. Auditors recommended the Board go through the State Procurement Office for direction before signing any future contracts. One lawmaker disagreed with the audit conclusion and said the board acted inappropriately.

stories.headline: Fallon entertains Walmart workers
stories.summary: Fallon hosted Walmart's 55th annual celebration for its workers at Bud Walton Arena in Fayetteville. The event featured performances by The Killers and Post Malone and included comedic and musical entertainment by Fallon, who poked fun at Walmart employees' use of self-checkout. Walmart is the No. 1 employer in Arkansas, employing thousands of workers from the region.

stories.headline: Disability advocacy group gets funding
stories.summary: Disability Rights Arkansas, a Little Rock-based advocacy organization providing services to Arkansans with disabilities, has accepted new clients despite previously warning it might have to cease operations over a lack of federal grant funding. The organization had paused the acceptance of new clients in late April due to delays in federal funding but now continues operations with the new funding.

stories.headline: Justices OK access to systems for DOGE
stories.summary: The Supreme Court handed the Trump administration two victories involving the Department of Government Efficiency, including access to Social Security systems containing sensitive data on millions. The justices supported in orders seeking transparency at DOGE, a team once led by Elon Musk. The court's conservative majority sided with the administration involving two appeals including this issue against privacy law restrictions. Three liberal justices dissented.

stories.headline: Escaped convict Hardin recaptured near prison
stories.summary: Grant Hardin, who was freed in an escape last week, was recaptured by Benton County Prosecuting Attorney Bryan Sexton. Hardin, a 56-year-old convicted of killing James Appleton and raping Amy Harrison, was serving a combined 80-year prison sentence. He was found near North Central Unit in Calico Rock wearing a sheriff outfit and tried to resemble a law enforcement officer when walking away. The community and Hardin's family expressed relief at his capture.

stories.headline: Jury finds Anderson guilty on all counts
stories.summary: Maxwell Anderson, a 34-year-old former bartender, was found guilty on all counts including first-degree intentional homicide in the April 2024 killing of Sade Carleena Robinson. The Milwaukee County jury's decision came after a nearly two-week trial and was highly emotional for Robinson's family, who had waited 14 months for justice. Robinson's mother, Sheena Scarbrough, expressed the heavy emotional impact of the verdict and said Sade would be remembered as an angel. Prosecutors successfully established Anderson and Robinson met for drinks, and Anderson later killed and dismembered her, with her remains found near a fire. A mandatory life sentence is expected, with an appeal planned.

stories.headline: Bill would ban certain additives in school food
stories.summary: A bipartisan proposal by Republican lawmakers, including Sen. Rachael Cabral-Guevara, Rep. Clint Moses, and Rep. R-Appleton, aims to ban specific additives from school meals. The proposal targets additives such as brominated vegetable oil, potassium bromate, propylparaben, azodicarbonamide, and others in an effort to improve the healthiness and safety of food served in schools. The proposed bill follows similar legislation in states like California and aligns with steps taken by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration and Department of Health and Human Services.

stories.headline: Johnson softens opposition to tax bill
stories.summary: Wisconsin Senator Ron Johnson, previously a critic of President Donald Trump's sweeping tax and spending bill, has softened his stance after private discussions with Trump and White House meetings. Johnson expressed a more positive outlook on the bill, indicating willingness to support it despite past concerns about the national debt and pre-pandemic spending levels. His change in demeanor is significant for the future of the proposed tax bill, although he acknowledged there are still issues to be addressed.

stories.headline: GOP urges Trump-Musk truce
stories.summary: The president and former DOGE leader clash over massive U.S. tax and border spending legislation. Republican Party braces for aftershocks from President Donald Trumps spectacular clash with Elon Musk, with lawmakers and conservative figures urging detente, fearful of the prolonged feuds consequences. Musk was posting about his various companies on social media rather than torching the president, who departed the White House without comment on the truce talk.

stories.headline: Longtime Tampa restaurant makes a big move to Ybor
stories.summary: The iconic fine dining spot Mise en Place will have a new location at the end of the year, relocating from West Kennedy Boulevard to the ground floor of the Casa Gomez building in Ybor City. Owner Maryann Ferenc aims to inspire others with the move and continue the restaurant's tradition of ambitious culinary ventures and excellent dining experiences, including the 39th year anniversary in September. The restaurant will close its current location by November and plans to carry forward loyal patronage at the new site.

stories.headline: Facing extinction, rare Florida swamp flower could get more protections
stories.summary: Federal wildlife officials announced a proposal to list the ghost orchid as an endangered species due to its drastic population decline in Florida, the only state where it exists in the U.S. Estimates put fewer than 1,000 ghost orchids remaining, with many unable to reproduce. Experts hail the listing as a lifeline to protect the species after decades of habitat loss and environmental threats caused a 90% population drop in recent decades.

stories.headline: Florida attorney general steps into land debate
stories.summary: Clearwater mayor received a letter from Florida attorney general James Uthmeier cautioning against religious discrimination amid a dispute involving the Church of Scientology and a city council decision about selling land downtown. The attorney general's letter warns that discriminatory motives could taint the council's decision making and frames any restrictions on approval as potentially a violation of Florida law.

stories.headline: Proud Boys local leader joins lawsuit against U.S.
stories.summary: A prominent local member of the Proud Boys has joined four other leaders in a federal lawsuit demanding more than $100 million in damages over their convictions related to the January 6, 2021 attack on the U.S. Capitol. The lawsuit challenges the government’s prosecution, alleging violation of constitutional rights as the defendant was convicted on sedition and other charges. The federal lawsuit was filed in Florida and cites a sweeping order from former President Donald Trump that pardoned and commuted sentences of many convicted on Jan. 6-related crimes.

stories.headline: Uncle Sam billboard along I-5 near Chehalis, famous for right-wing messages, sold to tribe
stories.summary: The highly contentious Uncle Sam billboard off Interstate 5 in Lewis County has been sold to the Confederated Tribes of the Chehalis Reservation for $2.5 million. The tribe intends to take down the right-wing messages that have lingered for over 13 years. The property is about 3.5 acres and holds historical significance, with the sale seen as an opportunity for economic development and repositioning of assets by the tribe.

stories.headline: State poised to undertake its first study of reparations
stories.summary: For the first time, Washington will conduct a study and develop proposals for reparations to descendants of chattel slavery. Approved in the state's $78 billion two-year budget, the study will examine the history of slavery in Washington and potential remedies, funding $300,000 to the landmark study. Advocates believe this pioneering effort could set frameworks for reparations such as cash payments, tuition scholarships, and other reparative justice measures to address systemic discrimination and racial disparities in the state.

stories.headline: How Sea-Tac is helping move more and more flyers through
stories.summary: Seattle-Tacoma International Airport opened a new security checkpoint to ease congestion and better direct travelers. The addition of Checkpoint 1, a new shiny security line located on the baggage claim level, complements the existing checkpoints and is designed to enhance passenger flow, especially during peak travel times. Airport staff, including the airport's manager of signage and wayfinding, have recently updated the signage to improve clarity and facilitate smooth movement through security and the airport overall.

stories.headline: Mistakenly deported man returned from El Salvador to face charges
stories.summary: Kilmar Abrego Garcia, a man at the center of political and legal maelstrom, was mistakenly deported to El Salvador and has now been flown back to the United States to face charges of illegally transporting migrants living in the country. The U.S. attorney general alleges this illegal transportation, with the decision to pull Abrego Garcia out of El Salvador drawing mixed reactions amid ongoing administration efforts to manage high-profile immigration court battles.

stories.headline: Tense standoff as immigration raids are reported across L.A.
stories.summary: In a show of force in the heart of Los Angeles, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents conducted a series of immigration sweeps across two downtown areas, sparking tense standoffs. Videos showed federal agents running after people in a parking lot and attempting to detain workers in the Garment District. Protesters gathered to voice opposition as agents, dressed in riot gear, attempted arrests, with immigrant rights advocates emphasizing constitutional protections and criticizing the administration's approach.

stories.headline: Abrego Garcia returned to U.S. to face criminal charges
stories.summary: Kilmar Abrego Garcia, whose detainment in El Salvador became a political flashpoint, has been brought back to the United States to face criminal charges related to human smuggling. The Trump administration had stepped up immigration enforcement, and Garcia's arrest stemmed from a large human smuggling operation. Although initial orders blocked his return, legal developments facilitated him coming back to the U.S. to confront the charges against him.

stories.headline: TRUMP'S BIG BILL FLAILS IN MUSK FALLOUT
stories.summary: Legislation known as the 'One Big Beautiful Bill Act' supported by President Trump's alliance with Elon Musk faced strong headwinds in the Senate over concerns about spending and moderate opposition. The bill, intended to counteract costly tax breaks and address various policy issues, confronted skepticism from Republican conservatives and moderates alike. Senate Majority Leader Ron Johnson emphasized budgetary constraints, reflecting the challenges in pushing forward expansive spending bills in the current Congress.

stories.headline: No surcharge on gas appliance sales, board says
stories.summary: The South Coast Air Quality Management District voted 7-5 against a controversial proposal to impose surcharges on natural gas-powered water heaters and furnaces aimed at reducing pollution. The board rejected the measure due to concerns it would unfairly penalize households and not target larger pollution sources such as refineries and shipping ports. Environmental advocates are divided, with some criticizing the decision as detrimental to air quality progress.

stories.headline: Jury finds O.C.'s Spitzer retaliated against prosecutor
stories.summary: Orange County District Attorney Todd Spitzer was found by a jury to have acted with malice against a high-ranking woman in his office, Tracy Miller. The jury concluded that Spitzer harassed and retaliated against Miller after she raised concerns about his conduct. The case, heard in San Diego County to avoid conflicts, found that Spitzer's actions included creating hostile work conditions and taking adverse employment measures against Miller, reflecting workplace harassment and abuse of power.

stories.headline: Coming up clutch
stories.summary: The Indiana Pacers, focused on the 2025 NBA Finals, are relying on the performance of guard Tyrese Haliburton as they face the Oklahoma City Thunder. Coach Rick Carlisle highlights the tension and effort, emphasizing trust in Haliburton's skills during critical moments in the game at Paycom Center.

stories.headline: Feud may not end well for former Trump ally Musk
stories.summary: Tensions have risen between former President Donald Trump and entrepreneur Elon Musk, with political figures expecting the feud to escalate negatively. The history of political allies turning adversaries is cited, with speculation that Musk's businesses could suffer due to the dispute. Prominent advisors and former officials predict a harsh political battle ahead.

stories.headline: Texts, key details omitted
stories.summary: The investigation into Indianapolis Mayor Joe Hogsett's handling of sexual harassment allegations faces criticism as women's accounts reportedly differ from the official report. The report omits key details such as late-night texts and personal messages from the mayor, making the women involved feel uncomfortable. Independently paid, the city spent $450,000 on the probe, amid claims of revictimization and minimized accusations.

stories.headline: Fed official: Iowa among most at risk from tariffs
stories.summary: Austan Goolsbee, president and CEO of the Chicago Federal Reserve, discussed the impacts of tariffs and the current economic conditions during a visit to Iowa. He noted that federal policy and tariffs have caused uncertainty for the U.S. and Iowa economy, citing Iowa as particularly affected due to its manufacturing and agricultural sectors and strong supply chain dependencies. Goolsbee highlighted concerns about economic indicators in Iowa showing signs of a downturn, while the Midwest is more focused on agriculture manufacturing.

stories.headline: Reynolds signs $1.2B employer tax cut bill
stories.summary: Gov. Kim Reynolds signed a bipartisan bill that will cut taxes on Iowa businesses by $1.2 billion over the next five years. The law lowers the amount businesses pay to the state's unemployment trust fund, reducing the unemployment tax rate from 7% to 5.4%. The bill aims to support Iowa's economy, keep jobs within the state, and make Iowa more competitive by lowering payroll taxes on wages that fund unemployment benefits.

stories.headline: Appeals court voids Story, Shelby counties’ pipeline ordinances
stories.summary: Summit Carbon Solutions achieved a legal victory when a federal appeals court ruled that Iowa's Story and Shelby counties cannot impose enhanced regulations on pipeline construction within their borders. The court upheld rulings that such county ordinances are preempted by federal law regulating pipeline construction and safety. The project to construct a $9 billion carbon dioxide pipeline has faced opposition, but the court's decision supports the pipeline company's ability to proceed.

stories.headline: Collins hopes to spare TRIO college access programs from Trump administration cuts
stories.summary: Senator Susan Collins and other lawmakers are fighting to preserve TRIO programs that help 7,500 Maine students, primarily low-income and disadvantaged youth, gain access to higher education. The Trump administration's proposed 2026 budget omits funding for TRIO programs, which include services such as academic support and college prep tools.

stories.headline: What’s on the ballot Tuesday for southern Maine voters
stories.summary: Southern Maine communities including Cape Elizabeth and Gorham prepare for the upcoming elections where budgets and bond projects will be closely contested. While many budgets have been approved easily in the past, some districts have faced rejections. Voters will decide on spending increases, school district funding, and bond projects despite the uncertain economic impacts linked to past pandemic conditions.

stories.headline: Katahdin: Here’s how to safely hike state’s tallest peak
stories.summary: Following the recent deaths of a father and daughter on Katahdin, New York native Cody McEwen shares insights on the dangers and how to safely hike the 5,267-foot mountain. McEwen, a seasoned hiker and Maine guide, notes that the risks are significant and not to be underestimated, highlighting the challenges posed by the terrain and unpredictable weather.

stories.headline: Maine’s next wildlife protection plan will consider climate change threats
stories.summary: Maine is developing its next wildlife action plan to include the impact of climate change on plants and animals. The plan will emphasize protecting habitats in response to climate threats, assessing native plants, and promoting the health of key species. The Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife will make use of new climate science to update conservation efforts.

stories.headline: Biddeford crew bids adieu
stories.summary: Biddeford High School faculty and graduates celebrated as staff members and seniors marched toward the gym to start the graduation ceremony. Over the weekend, other southern Maine schools including Westbrook, Scarborough and South Portland also held their graduations.

stories.headline: Tough trail race is child's play
stories.summary: Daniel Saucedo, a 12-year-old from San Juan Bautista, rises to the challenge of running the Dipsea Trail race, the most rugged trail race in the Bay Area. The race involves grueling obstacles and climbs, but Daniel enjoys the challenge and trains hard in preparation for the event.

stories.headline: Groups struggle after nonprofit's collapse
stories.summary: The San Francisco Parks Alliance, a nonprofit trusted with community funds, has collapsed financially, leaving neighbours and community groups without support to maintain local projects. This has jeopardized ongoing initiatives like the Steps to Wisdom public stairway, with uncertainties looming over debts and project completion.

stories.headline: Natural winery soars to top, then crashes
stories.summary: Subject Change Wine Co. aimed to become a top natural wine producer but faced severe challenges by March, leading to financial collapse. Owner Alex Pomerantz encountered problems with debt, crashing sales, and unpaid inventory piling up, highlighting the volatility in the natural wine business despite initial success.

stories.headline: World Cup, not in state budget, could cost 49ers
stories.summary: Governor Gavin Newsom's revised budget does not allocate state funds for next year's World Cup, putting financial pressure on the Bay Area's host committee, including the San Francisco 49ers, to cover tens of millions of dollars in expenses. While a nonprofit was hoping for state support, those funds are currently not planned, prompting concerns about funding and logistics.

stories.headline: UC, state brace for Trump to cut funds
stories.summary: California officials are preparing for possible federal funding cuts from the Trump administration, which may include eliminating grants for the University of California. There's concern about broader impacts on state funding, and officials are discussing their response to potential federal financial reductions tied to political disagreements.

stories.headline: Henry Ford Rochester nurses set to strike
stories.summary: Registered nurses at Henry Ford Rochester Hospital plan to strike from June 9-14 following a breakdown in contract negotiations with the hospital's administration. The strike, which would be the first in the hospital's 110-year history, is driven by disputes over wage increases, nurse-to-patient ratios, and staffing levels. The Office and Professional Employees International Union Local 40 has 374 nurse members at the hospital, advocating for safer staffing, reduced burnout, and improved patient care.

stories.headline: A Stand Against Violence of Guns
stories.summary: A public event against gun violence was held at Spirit Plaza in downtown Detroit on June 6, where protesters, police, and community leaders spoke out against the consequences of firearms. The event included memorable moments such as a hug between Pastor Barry Randolph and Detroit Police Chief Todd Bettison and featured the 'Spirit of Detroit' statue wearing an 'End Gun Violence' jersey.

stories.headline: New Trump travel ban draws outrage in Michigan
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's travel ban restricting people from 19 nations has sparked criticism in Michigan, especially from immigrant advocates and Arab and African community groups. The ban, effective June 9, is seen as targeting the Arab world and Africa disproportionately and has been labeled very unfortunate by local leaders, including Abdulkabir Alsadah, president of the Dearborn-based National Association of Yemeni Americans. The Executive Order was signed on May 5, despite significant opposition.

stories.headline: Trump seeks justices' approval to gut U.S. Education Department
stories.summary: The Trump administration has requested the Supreme Court's approval to dismantle the Education Department and fire hundreds of its workers, aiming to end the department and shift education policy control to states. Solicitor General John Sauer argued that only Congress can dictate the number of education employees. The case challenges the jurisdiction and authority over dismissing 1,300 workers, raising high-stakes legal questions about the Department's future.

stories.headline: Ruling OKs DOGE access of Social Security data
stories.summary: A divided Supreme Court ruled in favor of allowing the U.S. DOGE Service access to sensitive Social Security Administration data of millions of Americans, lifting limits on government systems that had restricted such information. The order supports the Trump administration's efforts to obtain agency data and counters legal challenges concerning privacy. The court's decision permits government watchdog groups to access information about the service, though it drew warnings from liberal justices about privacy risks.

stories.headline: Public broadcasters in Mich. cite risks under Trump cuts
stories.summary: The Trump administration's proposed cuts to federal funding for public broadcasting could cause severe financial damage and job losses to PBS and NPR stations in Michigan, according to officials from those outlets. Detroit Public Radio's WDET-FM, which receives an annual cash grant from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, is among the stations expected to be impacted. Staff and management express concerns that the cuts would be a serious blow, affecting jobs and programming, amid efforts by political leadership to reduce funding.

stories.headline: Dearborn pumps brakes on food trucks with new regulations
stories.summary: Dearborn officials have introduced new regulations for food trucks that will take effect in September. The new rules require food trucks to operate in designated parking lots, curb unsafe practices, and protect existing restaurants from unfair competition. Dearborn has 30 active food truck licenses, and the regulations respond to increased vendor growth and concerns about illegal dumping and safety issues. The measures aim to balance support for food trucks while addressing community concerns over noise, waste, and competition.

stories.headline: Two men held in foiled shooting at Pontiac graduation
stories.summary: The Oakland County Sheriff's Office arrested two men in connection with a foiled mass shooting planned at a Pontiac high school graduation. One suspect, Michael Bouchard, and the second suspect, Jamaar Hardiman, face charges after police discovered a pink AR-style pistol with a 40-round magazine and a black handgun with a 40-round stick magazine in their possession. The suspects allegedly intended to shoot up the graduation ceremony but were stopped after threats were reported. The guns were unregistered, and police continue efforts to locate the weapon owners.

stories.headline: When she said "bye," it's like she had a feeling
stories.summary: Chicago Police Officer Krystal Rivera's 10-year-old daughter cherishes their final embrace after Rivera was unintentionally shot and killed by her partner during a foot chase in Chatham. The story reflects on the tragic event and the daughter's poignant memory of her mother's last words.

stories.headline: Justin Ishbia, who could become Sox' majority owner, is no stranger to local political controversy
stories.summary: Justin Ishbia, a potential majority owner of the Chicago White Sox, is involved in multiple local political controversies. The story provides background on Ishbia's political activities and the implications for his potential ownership role in the team.

stories.headline: Tears and tension outside immigration center as supporters demand release of ICE detainees
stories.summary: Supporters gathered outside an immigration center in a state of tears and tension, demanding the release of detainees held by ICE. The protest highlights ongoing concerns about immigration enforcement and the treatment of detainees.

stories.headline: Immigration watchdogs kept from outside court
stories.summary: Activists and journalists gathered outside a federal immigration court in late May to help migrants attending hearings know their legal rights and to protest deportation efforts. However, because the court is in a private office building, police enforced no trespassing rules and ordered activists to leave, limiting their ability to report and protest. Advocates questioned why the courthouse is taxpayer-funded but restricts public presence on its property.

stories.headline: Pitcher’s season is over
stories.summary: The Arizona Diamondbacks' pitcher Corbin Burnes will undergo Tommy John surgery, ending his season prematurely. Burnes signed a club-record $210 million contract less than six months ago.

stories.headline: Axon has top-paid CEO
stories.summary: Axon CEO Rick Smith received a total compensation package worth roughly $31,200 daily, including stock awards valued at nearly $164.5 million in 2024. This makes him the highest-paid CEO last year according to the Wall Street Journal.

stories.headline: Small plane crash injures 2
stories.summary: A small plane crashed near Deer Valley Airport, resulting in injuries to two individuals. Emergency responders worked at the scene and a crew moved the damaged aircraft after the incident.

stories.headline: Negotiators for Colorado River water face grim climate outlooks
stories.summary: Negotiators and scientists gathered to discuss the future of the Colorado River, recognizing the challenges of balancing supply and demand amid a warming climate. The region is expected to experience temperature increases of 3 to 5 degrees Celsius by 2100, which will strain water resources critical to the West. This poses serious concerns for how to share and manage the river's diminishing flow in the coming decades.

stories.headline: Arizona public schools are bracing for less state money
stories.summary: Arizona's public schools will experience a reduction in state aid starting in June due to higher than projected costs at the Department of Education. The estimated $206.2 million shortfall will affect district and charter schools, primarily impacting about 60% of their regular monthly funds. Factors include higher costs to settle a property tax lawsuit, increased demand for private school vouchers, and higher enrollment in public schools. Financial officers express concern about the impact on budgets and ability to make payroll, with some districts planning to hold off discretionary spending.

stories.headline: President Finds a Rival Who Can Punch Back
stories.summary: President Trump faces strong opposition from Elon Musk, owner of SpaceX and Tesla, in a battle of political and social media influence. Their rivalry represents a new challenge for Trump as Musk's platform, X, and Twitter hold significant sway. The conflict highlights vulnerabilities and power struggles between the two titans, affecting policy, public opinion, and future political strategies.

stories.headline: A Bright Spot Among the Rubble
stories.summary: Children enjoyed a trampoline in Gaza City during the Muslim holiday Eid al-Adha, bringing a moment of joy amid the destruction and funerals held elsewhere in the Gaza Strip. This story highlights resilience and hopeful moments amid ongoing conflict and humanitarian challenges.

stories.headline: Trams Troops Staring Down An Ultimatum
stories.summary: The Trump administration ordered transgender troops to leave the military, giving them the choice to voluntarily exit or face separation. The deadline is approaching rapidly, causing uncertainty and potential disciplinary repercussions. The troops face a critical decision that could affect their military careers and personal lives.

stories.headline: Justices Grant DOGE Access To Private Data
stories.summary: The Supreme Court granted members of the Department of Government Efficiency, led by Elon Musk, access to sensitive records of many millions of Americans held by the Social Security Administration. The order comes without emergency appeals and aims to tackle waste and fraud, showing Musk's expanding influence in governmental oversight and privacy-related controversies.

stories.headline: Housing Slump, Defying Hopes, Has Not Eased
stories.summary: Despite hopes for a market revival, the housing market continues to struggle with slow growth amid economic and inflation issues. Buyers and sellers face challenges with mortgage rates and market volatility, stalling recovery efforts and keeping housing market conditions tough for many.

stories.headline: Man Expelled in Error Returns, And Now He’ll Be Prosecuted
stories.summary: Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia was mistakenly deported to El Salvador after being at the center of a U.S. immigration and legal rights debate. Upon return, the Trump administration claims he aided smuggling migrants and has filed charges against him, casting a spotlight on the harsh immigration enforcement tactics and government accountability.

stories.headline: Eight Deported Convicts Wait In East Africa, Far From Home
stories.summary: Eight men deported from the United States under Homeland Security Department orders have been held in Camp Lemonnier, an American military base in Djibouti, East Africa. They are living in poor conditions in a container with limited comforts. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers handle the detainees who are facing uncertain futures, reflecting controversial immigration enforcement policies.

stories.headline: Trump-Musk quarrel reopens a GOP fault line
stories.summary: Tensions between former President Trump and Elon Musk have re-ignited a fault line within the Republican Party regarding the use and political signature of Twitter. Fiscal hawks and conservatives debate the implications of Musk’s control and policies on Twitter, leading to disputes among GOP figures over party direction and influence. The quarrel underscores existing disagreements within the party about strategy and digital communication.

stories.headline: Abrego García is returned to U.S. to face charges
stories.summary: Salvadoran man Abrego García, who was deported under the Trump administration, has been returned to the U.S. and charged with human smuggling. The Supreme Court ordered the government to facilitate his return, overturning a previous deportation that was challenged by his lawyers. He faces prosecution in U.S. courts after breaching immigration orders. The case has sparked debate between attorneys and officials regarding the legality and enforcement of immigration laws under differing administrations.

stories.headline: City leaders ask if Norton remains D.C.'s ‘warrior’
stories.summary: Several elected officials and allies are questioning whether Eleanor Holmes Norton, D.C.'s longest-serving delegate in the House, retains the vigor and fitness to effectively advocate for the District at age 87. Concerns have been raised regarding her responsiveness and engagement amid challenges for reelection and D.C.’s political future. Despite her long tenure, scrutiny is increasing on her ability to meet the demands of her role going forward.

stories.headline: A return to Syria — and difficult memories
stories.summary: Photographer Salwan Georges visited Syria to document the aftermath of Bashar al-Assad’s regime’s retreat and the difficult conditions in areas formerly under government control. The visit reveals the ongoing hardship faced by residents, including damaged homes and reports of torture. The story reflects on the impact of war and displacement over time through powerful visual storytelling.

stories.headline: Feds fence off Dupont Circle Park
stories.summary: The National Park Service ordered the closure of Dupont Circle Park for the first time during Pride weekend to address security concerns after an outcry from the LGBTQ community. The Park, a central site for Pride celebrations, was fenced off after the discovery of uncertainty among community members and elected officials about safety, following threats and heightened tensions around the event. Several council members and neighborhood commissioners opposed the closure but ultimately it was implemented as a measure to ensure public safety for the weekend.

stories.headline: Scramble is on after too many people fired by DOGE
stories.summary: The Food and Drug Administration's Drug Office for Generic Entities (DOGE) fired nearly 50 workers abruptly, leading to disarray and challenges as the agency attempts to turn operations around. After significant dismissals including probationary employees, there is concern about performance and staffing levels. The reshuffle is seen as part of broader efforts to improve regulatory oversight but creates immediate organizational disruption and impacts employee morale.

stories.headline: Cabinet comes out West
stories.summary: Four top Trump administration officials are expected to come to Santa Fe to headline the 2025 Western Governors' Association meeting. This will bring attention and a gathering of significant presidential administration figures to New Mexico, marking a notable political event for the state and the region.

stories.headline: Navigating past built-up tensions
stories.summary: This story examines efforts in New Mexico, focusing on local ecosystems involving beavers, acequias, and watersheds. It highlights how these natural factors interact and advocates explore ways to foster healthy coexistence, especially around ongoing water allocation disputes in Taos and the role of beavers in sustaining riparian environments.

stories.headline: Pro-migrant groups facing intimidation, spending cuts
stories.summary: Despite Trump's mass deportations not heavily impacting New Mexico yet, immigrant populations and their advocates report increased fear from arrests and intimidation. Community organizers working with young immigrants face challenges amid cuts to federal funding and threats, affecting the local immigrant community's sense of safety and support.

stories.headline: Doctors were about to take their organs, until they woke up
stories.summary: A federal investigation uncovered that a Kentucky organ donation nonprofit overlooked signs of growing alertness in unconscious patients, leading to cases where organ removal was nearly conducted on individuals who regained consciousness. The investigation reviewed about 350 cases and revealed systemic issues in the coordination and timing of organ donations.

stories.headline: Palestinians recount deadly shooting near Gaza aid site
stories.summary: Palestinians recount their desperate efforts to secure food at an Israeli-backed aid site in Rafah, Gaza Strip, following nearly three months without aid deliveries. The situation escalated with violent clashes as thousands attempted to reach the distribution point, resulting in a deadly shooting and highlighting the ongoing humanitarian crisis in the region.

stories.headline: Top court lets DOGE access data in Social Security
stories.summary: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), allowing it access to Social Security data containing personal information on millions of Americans. This decision is part of a broader Trump administration effort, with the court's conservative majority supporting the administration's position, while three liberal justices dissented. The DOGE's case has caused tension between political figures and has significant implications for data transparency and governance.

stories.headline: Migrant returned to US, charged
stories.summary: Kilmar Abrego Garcia was returned to the United States to face criminal charges related to human smuggling after mistakenly being deported to El Salvador. His case highlights the intensified immigration enforcement under the Trump administration and its impact on deportation and immigrant rights.

stories.headline: Giving ICE the cold shoulder
stories.summary: Federal records show that 86 of 95 sheriffs across Tennessee have yet to enter into agreements with federal immigration officials as of late, displaying hesitation in joining the program that delegates immigration enforcement powers to local law enforcement. The program overseen by ICE aims to expedite deportations but has faced mixed participation among rural sheriffs due to cost concerns and other factors, despite efforts by state lawmakers to increase enrollment and funding.

stories.headline: Visit Ithaca’s best outdoor destinations
stories.summary: As summer arrives in the Finger Lakes region, Ithaca offers numerous natural attractions including well-known walks, waterfalls, parks for picnics, and hiking trails. Featured destinations are Taughannock Falls State Park, Black Diamond Trail, Watkins Glen State Park, Stewart Park, Dryden Rail Trail, and Cascadilla Gorge Trail, each providing unique outdoor experiences such as scenic trails, waterfalls, camping, fishing, and off-road transportation.

stories.headline: Trump’s fast start has hit speed bumps
stories.summary: President Donald Trump faces significant challenges in advancing his domestic agenda despite initial momentum. Congressional opposition, ongoing military engagements, and mixed signals from conflicting forces complicate his administration's efforts. The article analyzes the hurdles including criticism from both Democrats and within the White House, along with geopolitical pressures like the Ukraine conflict, indicating an uncertain path ahead for the president's policy goals.

stories.headline: Two rescued black bear cubs released back into wild
stories.summary: Two black bear cubs that suffered through a harsh winter of isolation and malnutrition were rescued and released back into their natural habitat in the Adirondacks after rehabilitation. The cubs were cared for by the Friends of the Feathered and Furry Wildlife Center in Greene County, with assistance from the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation. The successful release highlights collaborative efforts for wildlife conservation.

stories.headline: MorseLife to pay execs directly
stories.summary: MorseLife Health Systems in West Palm Beach is ending its pay arrangement that funneled $35.9 million in compensation through a private entity, Amplifi Management LLC. Going forward, top executives such as CEO Keith Myers and CFO Randy Wolan will be paid directly by MorseLife, with pay disclosed in normal course filings. This change follows scrutiny and concerns from donors and the Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County regarding transparency of MorseLife’s finances.

stories.headline: County suspends all its DEI programs
stories.summary: Palm Beach County commissioners have suspended all Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) programs to avoid risking more than $600 million in federal and state funding. These programs funded airport improvements, highway work, and other capital projects. The decision comes as the Office of Equal Business Opportunity can no longer contract with women- and minority-owned businesses. A requirement for contractors to hire certified women- and minority-owned businesses had been part of these DEI initiatives.

stories.headline: UF chair unhappy with Ono rejection
stories.summary: University of Florida Board of Trustees Chair Mori Hosseini expressed deep disappointment over the Board of Governors’ decision to reject Dr. Santa Ono as UF’s 14th president. Hosseini praised Ono's qualifications and lamented the missed opportunity for the university. He stressed that the rejection should not diminish the University of Florida's momentum despite the news being disappointing for the UF community.

stories.headline: Musk-Trump rift widens with threat to contracts
stories.summary: The escalating conflict between Elon Musk and President Donald Trump has grown over disagreements concerning tax legislation. Musk, the world's richest man, criticized the tax bill championed by Trump and Speaker Mike Johnson, while Trump responded by dismissing Musk's statements as false. This feud threatens the continuation of contracts and has sparked a public exchange of insults, highlighting the sharp divides within the MAGA movement.

stories.headline: City social workers are overburdened, advocates testify
stories.summary: Philadelphia's Department of Human Services faces challenges with an overburdened foster care system, partly due to outsourcing and inadequate funding levels that do not cover the average social worker's case load. Child welfare advocates and city council members testified on the need for improved resources and policies to better support families and children in the system. Efforts continue to address caseload sizes and improve foster care outcomes.

stories.headline: No sign of any truce in the Trump-Musk big, beautiful breakup
stories.summary: Former President Donald Trump continued his feud with Elon Musk, criticizing Musk on national television and rejecting attempts at reconciliation. The dispute stems from Musk's recent comments and the failed proposed budget legislation considered a 'disgusting abomination' by Trump. Political analysts note the ongoing hostility impacts both figures' public relations and political standings.

stories.headline: Prayers amid war's ruins
stories.summary: Amid the destruction in Gaza caused by Israeli bombardment, Palestinians gathered to offer Eid al-Adha prayers beside the ruins of a mosque in Deir al-Balah. Many participants expressed hope that the holiday's spirit will inspire peace in the near future, despite the ongoing conflict and hardship.

stories.headline: Wrongly deported man back in the U.S., charged
stories.summary: Kilmar Abrego Garcia, who was mistakenly deported to El Salvador during the Trump administration's immigration enforcement efforts, has been returned to the United States and faces criminal charges related to a massive human smuggling operation. His abrupt release from El Salvador sparked a complex standoff and drew attention to mistakes made in deportation processes. The case has political and legal significance as authorities pursue prosecutions in smuggling cases.

stories.headline: DOGE's big mistake: It fired too many people
stories.summary: The Food and Drug Administration recently fired nearly 50 workers in the Office of Regulatory Policy on short notice, causing operational disruptions. The dismissals were part of a broader pattern under the Trump administration to reduce workforce, leading to concerns about the agency's ability to manage regulatory work effectively. The IRS also reversed course on layoffs after pushback. The article questions whether DOGE might reconsider its staffing decisions to better support the agency's vital functions.

stories.headline: Court OKs DOGE access to Social Security
stories.summary: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), allowing the agency to access Social Security systems containing personal data on millions of Americans. The decision came after the court's conservative majority sided with the Trump administration in the first Supreme Court appeals involving DOGE, despite dissent from three liberal justices. The ruling is part of a broader move to increase government efficiency, though there are concerns over privacy safeguards and data access.

stories.headline: Officials say '500 in 500' on track
stories.summary: Allegheny County's '500 in 500' housing initiative, led by Executive Sara Innamorato, remains on track to meet its housing targets by placing 500 people into housing and creating 500 new units within 500 days. Despite recent concerns about matching for the created units, the program continues to make progress toward its goal of affordable housing in the region.

stories.headline: Widespread flooding
stories.summary: Heavy rainfall caused flooding in Murrysville, leading to vehicle submersion and evacuations in Plum and Monroeville. The flooding persisted under a flood warning through the evening. Fortunately, no serious injuries have been reported as residents coped with the extreme weather event.

stories.headline: Church asks court to allow festival despite concern
stories.summary: A church in Moon Township requested a court to permit a weeklong festival on its property later this month despite opposition and concerns raised after a previous year's event. Revival Today Church filed a motion and a judge is reviewing a preliminary injunction to determine if the event can proceed in compliance with local zoning and permitting rules.

stories.headline: Bill blocks some from full child tax credit
stories.summary: Low-income families earning up to $400,000 may see a $500 bump in the child tax credit under a House-approved Republican tax and spending plan that blocks some working families from receiving the full $2,500 credit. The legislation aims to support families with groceries and bills but does not eliminate the 'cliff' effect where some families lose full benefits abruptly.

stories.headline: GOP fumes as tax bill runs into difficulty
stories.summary: The Republican Party's effort to pass a tax bill has encountered significant challenges, inflaming the already strained relationship between Elon Musk and President Donald Trump. The bill's reopening caused tensions over key issues like Medicare and Social Security, with Speaker Mike Johnson and other Republicans expressing frustration about crafting legislation under current political pressures.

stories.headline: Abrego Garcia returned to U.S.
stories.summary: Kilmar Abrego Garcia, mistakenly deported to El Salvador and a political flashpoint during the Trump administration, was returned to the U.S. to face human smuggling charges. His release reopened a contentious standoff between Trump officials and the courts regarding his deportation error. Garcia is expected to be prosecuted and potentially returned to El Salvador after the case concludes.

stories.headline: Budget ax could fall on Decatur
stories.summary: Decatur city officials face potential loss of $16 million in federal funding for the Bill Sims Bicycle Trail after the House rescinded $18.4 million previously allocated through the Reconnecting Communities Pilot and Neighborhood Access Equity discretionary grant program. Mayor Tab Bowling expressed disappointment but remains optimistic that the next administration will continue pursuing funding efforts. The decision came from Washington D.C. and poses a significant setback to local infrastructure improvements along the Tennessee River and northwest Decatur.

stories.headline: Trump and Musk urged to end feud
stories.summary: The Republican Party is reacting to the ongoing public clash between President Donald Trump and Elon Musk, urging for détente to avoid damaging conservative unity. Lawmakers and conservative figures fear the feud could undermine key policy goals, including Republicans' massive tax and border spending legislation. Representatives and senators expressed hope that the two will reconcile to maintain party strength and avoid distractions ahead of important legislative efforts.

stories.headline: Mack seeks to add deputy chief
stories.summary: Just four days into his new job, Police Chief Torry Mack is moving quickly to bring in his own staff to lead the Decatur Police Department. The city's Personnel Board agreed to recommend Mack's request to add a deputy chief position, aiming to fill the role with a long-time friend and colleague, former Birmingham Police Lt. Eric Stisher. Mack emphasized the need for a deputy chief to ensure 100% command oversight and to maintain department operations especially during his absence.

stories.headline: REMEMBERING THE HEROES OF D-DAY
stories.summary: A ceremony at the American Cemetery in Colleville-sur-Mer, France, commemorated the 81st anniversary of D-Day, attended by US veteran Jake Larson and other participants honoring the sacrifices of WWII heroes.

stories.headline: Report says state neglected records of those in its care
stories.summary: David Scott’s family recalls that the state failed to properly preserve records about his older brother John, who was institutionalized and died young. The story highlights issues with state care systems, poor record keeping, and the impact on families seeking information about their loved ones.

stories.headline: Town’s immigrant past informs present
stories.summary: Milford officials and community members grapple with immigration and deportation issues following the detention of a young Brazilian immigrant. The town’s multicultural background and local immigrant population face challenges amid shifting immigration policies and societal tensions.

stories.headline: Lynch seeks leadership role at tricky time
stories.summary: Boston Representative Stephen Lynch aims to become the top Democrat on a key House committee after losing a previous bid. The struggle reflects broader tensions within the Democratic Party between experience and new blood, as well as debates over generational change. Lynch is one of four Democrats seeking to lead the Oversight Committee, which has a heavy investigative role.

stories.headline: Migrant is back in US from El Salvador
stories.summary: Kilmar Abrego Garcia was mistakenly deported to El Salvador but flown back to the US to face human smuggling charges. The Trump administration's decision to deport him sparked a legal battle over immigration enforcement and President Trump's authority to rapidly seize and deport immigrants. Garcia is now held on trial in an American court.

stories.headline: QUEER PROMS ARE ABOUT JOY — AND RESPITE
stories.summary: Nicole Amaturo, a nonbinary high school senior, along with other students, organized an alternative queer prom called Queer Youth Boogie Night at Hingham High School. Despite facing online harassment, students are creating safe spaces for celebration amid challenges to DEI and trans rights.

stories.headline: Voters have last chance at runoffs
stories.summary: Voters across North Texas face key runoff elections for city council seats in Dallas and McKinney. The elections will decide tight races, including potentially replacing council members who have reached their term limits. The city's southernmost district is expected to see a major change, and several incumbent officials risk losing their seats in the runoff scheduled for Saturday.

stories.headline: Holiday prayers bring faithful together
stories.summary: Eid al-Adha, the Islamic holiday marking the willingness of Prophet Ibrahim to sacrifice his son, was celebrated on a Tuesday evening. Romanians gathered in Bucharest to pray, with additional prayers held in Gaza. The event showcases the unity and faith of the Muslim community worldwide during this significant religious occasion.

stories.headline: Deported man returns to U.S. to face charges
stories.summary: Kilmar Abrego Garcia, who was deported to El Salvador, has been returned to the United States to face criminal charges connected to a Trump administration crackdown on immigration. Abrego Garcia allegedly led a smuggling operation that brought immigrants into the country illegally, leading to a standoff between U.S. authorities and El Salvador. The case has raised concerns and questions about American justice and immigration enforcement policies.

stories.headline: DeBoer fired after 3 seasons
stories.summary: Pete DeBoer was fired as head coach of the Dallas Stars after leading the team to three consecutive Western Conference finals appearances. The decision came just days after the team's owner downplayed reports that DeBoer was on his way out. The Dallas Stars' GM, Jim Nill, stated that a new voice was needed to push the team closer to their goal of winning the Stanley Cup and thanked DeBoer for his contributions.

stories.headline: Veterans return to Normandy
stories.summary: Veterans gathered in Normandy to mark the 81st anniversary of the D-Day landings, a pivotal moment in World War II leading to the collapse of Adolf Hitler's regime. The event included parachute jumps, flyovers, and historical reenactments, with many attendees being elderly veterans in their 90s and older. The commemoration honored the sacrifices of those who fought during the invasion and reflected on the ongoing global conflicts, with U.S. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth drawing parallels to current wars.

stories.headline: First BSO negotiations since ’19 lockout begin
stories.summary: The Baltimore Symphony Orchestra has started bargaining with its first musicians’ contract since the 2019 financial crisis that severely impacted Maryland’s major art organization. These negotiations mark a critical step towards restoring financial and labor stability at the institution.

stories.headline: Trooper sentenced to 6 years for soliciting bribes
stories.summary: A Maryland State Police trooper was sentenced to six years in federal prison after admitting to passing information to a suspect in a drug case in exchange for cash. This conviction highlights ongoing concerns with corruption in law enforcement.

stories.headline: Supreme Court allows DOGE to access Social Security systems
stories.summary: The Supreme Court cleared the Department of Government Efficiency to access Social Security systems containing personal data on millions of Americans, siding with the Trump administration's first Supreme Court appeal involving DOGE. The decision permits DOGE to access data to fight fraud and verify government access but raises concerns about privacy risks and repeated access to sensitive personal information.

stories.headline: Youth fund loses grants as it sends millions to mayor’s office
stories.summary: The Maryland Department of Human Services' taxpayer-backed Baltimore Children and Youth Fund faces significant fund cuts as it reallocates millions to the Mayor Brandon Scott's office. The fund was scheduled to receive $16.5 million in fiscal year 2026, but after grant budget decreases, only $9.23 million remains. The fund historically supports youth organizations but now faces complications due to reallocation.

stories.headline: Combs’ ex-girlfriend sobs in court during testimony
stories.summary: A woman involved with Sean 'Diddy' Combs broke down during testimony about her heavily drug-fueled sex marathons, where the music mogul ignored her signals to stop. This dramatic courtroom moment highlighted allegations against the music industry star.

stories.headline: D-Day veterans return to Normandy, France
stories.summary: World War II veteran Jake Larson led ceremonies in Colleville-sur-Mer, Normandy, France, commemorating the 81st anniversary of the D-Day landings. The memorial event honored the legacy and sacrifices of veterans who participated in the historic Normandy invasion.

stories.headline: Lost aid abroad, prayers at home
stories.summary: Federal cuts have severely impacted Baltimore relief organizations that assist global humanitarian efforts, particularly in northern Kenya. Bill O’Keefe, the executive vice president of Catholic Relief Services, expressed sorrow over the loss of aid to drought-affected areas. Increased humanitarian needs and US Agency for International Development funding cuts have left many vulnerable people without necessary support.

stories.headline: Abrego Garcia returns to US, faces charges
stories.summary: Kilmar Abrego Garcia was returned to the US to face a federal indictment in Tennessee accusing him of trafficking people illegally across the country. His return comes after months of legal disputes and defiance by the Trump administration against U.S. orders to return him. The indictment alleges involvement in drug and people trafficking across several states. U.S. Attorney Pam Bondi confirmed the charges and mentioned previous refusals to release Garcia by El Salvadoran President Bukele.

stories.headline: Harbor East turtles 'doing well' after spill
stories.summary: Maryland wildlife crews reported that turtles in the Baltimore harbor were 'doing well' after thousands of gallons of fuel overflowed into the water near Harbor East. Cleanup efforts are ongoing, led by the Maryland Department of the Environment’s Oil Control Program, with a recovery team also rescuing three adult geese. The spill has abated as cleanup continues.

stories.headline: Texas Dream Act author, experts warn repeal a detriment to state
stories.summary: Rick Noriega, author of the Texas Dream Act, and other experts warn that repealing the act would harm Texas by forcing many students to pay out-of-state tuition they cannot afford. The law helps students who lack legal immigration status but meet certain residency requirements to access in-state tuition. Removing these protections could negatively impact education access and the state's workforce development, especially in cases like that of the featured student who overcame many barriers to attend college.

stories.headline: Whitmire excludes housing in aid plan
stories.summary: Mayor John Whitmire's administration decided against using disaster cash for home repairs in its spending plan for hurricane recovery, following federal advice. Instead, funds will be allocated toward generators, police and fire stations, multi-service centers, and water facilities. Despite identifying an estimated $230 million for housing needs after storms, officials chose not to spend on repairing housing stock, citing priorities in emergency response and infrastructure.

stories.headline: Jury finds man guilty in officer's slaying
stories.summary: Oscar Rosales was found guilty of capital murder in the shooting death of a deputy constable at precinct 5. The jury deliberated for two hours before returning the verdict. Prosecutors argued Rosales fired on a patrol SUV while claiming self-defense, but the jury’s decision suggests otherwise. Rosales could face the death penalty. The verdict followed testimony from family members of the victim and scenes from the courtroom.

stories.headline: Local groups see EPA grants vanish
stories.summary: Local groups in Houston express concern over the Environmental Protection Agency's cancellation of grants that were crucial to funding programs aimed at protecting human health and the environment. The EPA is reviewing all grants to ensure no inappropriate use of taxpayer dollars, a move that critics say undermines environmental justice and DEI programs. These changes threaten funding for many initiatives in the Houston metropolitan area, including those related to air pollution cleanup and community outreach efforts.

stories.headline: COP REMEMBERED AS ‘HARD WORKER’
stories.summary: Chicago police officer Krystal Rivera was shot and killed in Chatham, with the autopsy confirming she was struck in the back after a tactical team’s investigatory stop. The Chicago Police Department continues to investigate the shooting that took the life of the 4-year department veteran. Authorities said Rivera, 36, was known for her dedication and was a proud officer with a young daughter. City officials and department brass expressed sorrow and a commitment to keep the community informed as the investigation proceeds.

stories.headline: Trump, Musk schism rattling Republicans
stories.summary: Tensions between former President Donald Trump and Elon Musk have caused unease within the Republican Party. The disagreement centers around Trump’s praise for Musk’s Tesla purchase contrasted with Musk's backlash over Trump's role in the administration. Trump has no plans to sell Musk’s Tesla despite public calls, and the friction has led to concerns about party unity. White House officials stated Trump has little interest in engaging with Musk, with Musk threatening space agency decommissioning in response to policy moves.

stories.headline: An 'evolving target' for hatred amid Pride Month
stories.summary: Threats against drag performers have decreased as opposition within the LGBTQ community has shifted focus towards transgender and gender-nonconforming people, according to a new report. The atmosphere surrounding drag shows and Pride Month events shows a mixture of support and protest, with family-friendly events drawing larger crowds. Supporters of drag events emphasize the need to protect these spaces as hate evolves, urging vigilance against ongoing threats to LGBTQ communities.

stories.headline: Johnson promises to resist subpoena
stories.summary: U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement subpoenaed the Chicago city clerk’s office demanding personal information of applicants for the CityKey municipal ID program. Mayor Brandon Johnson has indicated he will resist efforts by federal authorities to obtain these records, citing concerns for the privacy and trust of individuals who participated in the program. The CityKey program, launched in 2017, has previously drawn opposition from Republican leadership. The city has not yet provided any documents related to the program to ICE as a result of the subpoena.

stories.headline: Scientists Can’t Stop Watching Seagulls Steal Your Food
stories.summary: The surprising and complex eating habits of seagulls have captured scientific attention. Researchers study how seagulls adapt to human food sources, their diverse diets, and their impact on humans, revealing fascinating bird behavior at coastal locations.

stories.headline: Another Musk Problem: Cybertruck
stories.summary: The production of Tesla's Cybertruck has encountered delays and complications, with the electric vehicle manufacturer missing early expectations. Problems range from supply chain issues to Tesla's approach to building components, causing investors and customers concern over the launch timeline and costs.

stories.headline: Pentagon Fueled UFO Mythology, Then Tried Coverup
stories.summary: A Pentagon investigation into UFO sightings and research into unidentified aerial phenomena was sometimes accompanied by efforts to foster mythology and secrecy. Military officials promoted and then suppressed information, a tactic that complicates public understanding of the phenomena.

stories.headline: Their Star-Crossed Bromance Implodes in Spectacular Fashion
stories.summary: The friendship and business relationship between Elon Musk and Twitter's co-founder has ended abruptly amid recent tensions. Musk's plans to significantly change Twitter led to public clashes, with the former close allies now at odds over the direction of the social media platform.

stories.headline: Hiring Slowed Slightly In May
stories.summary: U.S. job growth slowed slightly in May, with 139,000 jobs added, below expectations and the prior month's 177,000. The unemployment rate held steady at 4.2%, indicating cautious hiring amid economic uncertainty and tariff concerns. Despite the slowdown, some stocks jumped with positive market reactions.

stories.headline: D-Day Vets Return to Normandy, 81 Years Later
stories.summary: On the 81st anniversary of the D-Day landings, veterans including 102-year-old Jake Larson are honored at a ceremony at the American Cemetery in Colleville-sur-Mer, France. This event commemorates the Allied operation that was pivotal in World War II.

stories.headline: State House sues Benson over election training materials
stories.summary: The Michigan House of Representatives filed a lawsuit against Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson for refusing to fully comply with a subpoena to provide election training materials. The lawsuit alleges Benson's office defied a judge's order to hand over the materials in a timely manner. House Oversight Committee Chair Jay DeBoyer criticized Benson's continued defiance despite legislative oversight. The suit, heard in Michigan Court of Claims, follows unresolved attempts to obtain training documents sought by House Republicans.

stories.headline: Utility says it plans to unload its hydroelectric dam fleet
stories.summary: Consumers Energy is negotiating to sell its hydroelectric dams, claiming they are too expensive to operate. The utility confirmed ongoing sale talks covering 13 dams and related facilities on five rivers. Consumers Energy spokesperson Brian Wheeler stated that selling the dams is viewed as the best option for their customers, emphasizing ongoing negotiations with potential buyers but no final decisions yet. The sale would mark a significant change in energy resources management in the region, with local residents concerned about potential impacts from the sale and changes to dams and impoundments.

stories.headline: As student loan collections resume, borrowers are confused
stories.summary: With student loan collections starting again, many borrowers are baffled by the process as the Education Department resumes default loans collection on $3.3 million borrowers. The department previously paused income-driven repayment plans and borrower applications after federal court rulings. Borrowers enrolled in the SAVE plan are facing administrative forbearance due to legal challenges, delaying loan forgiveness and repayment processes. The system's complexity and legal uncertainties cause continued confusion and delays for borrowers trying to understand their repayment options.

stories.headline: Mpls. violence prevention workers face gun charges
stories.summary: Two workers involved in Minneapolis violence prevention were charged with shooting about 30 bullets in a residential neighborhood, with one bullet hitting a person in the neck and torso. The charges include felony weapons and reckless discharge of a firearm. The shooting apparently stemmed from a conflict involving the violence prevention workers themselves.

stories.headline: Proud Boys leaders sue U.S. for $100M
stories.summary: Five leaders of the Proud Boys filed a lawsuit against the U.S. government seeking $100 million in restitution over claims that their constitutional rights were violated. The suit alleges that their Jan. 6 charges were politically motivated and that the Trump administration used the prosecution to target them unfairly. The lawsuit contends the attempt to recast the events as an insurrection was an extraordinary and illegitimate use of power.

stories.headline: Walz calls special session Monday
stories.summary: Minnesota Governor Tim Walz and legislators reached a $66 billion state budget deal to avoid a partial government shutdown. A special session will be held on Monday to pass the agreement that covers a two-year budget and ends weeks of negotiations. Walz stated the bipartisan pact will result in necessary spending cuts and is the result of many hours of debate. Legislative partners were thanked for their dedication to moving Minnesota forward.

stories.headline: Driver guilty of murder in car crash that killed 5
stories.summary: A man was convicted on all charges related to a car crash in Lake St. that killed five people and devastated the Somali community. The driver was found guilty of killing five members of the community, including Sabriin Ali, Sahra Gesaade, Salma Abdikadir, Sagal Hersi and Siham Adam. The crash happened when the driver was speeding, driving at more than 110 miles per hour, and failed to stop at a red light. The verdict was a moment of sorrow and justice for the grieving families and community.

stories.headline: U plans tuition hikes, academic program cuts
stories.summary: The University of Minnesota is proposing dramatic tuition increases next year, including a 6.5% tuition jump for in-state undergraduate students on the Twin Cities campus. If approved, it would be the highest price spike in 14 years. The university blames anticipated flat funding from the state and declining federal support for research for the planned 7% cut in academic programming for the proposed 2025-26 budget. The $5.1 billion proposal also includes a 4% bump in faculty and staff compensation.
